docs.lead_paragraph: I got an e-mail last week with my health insurance renewal rates for 2012. (I have written extensively on this subject: on previous rate declines, on the subsequent feedback, on the health care overhaul, and on rates for older workers.) I opened the e-mail with some trepidation, given the general trend of substantial increases every year. Surprise! Another decrease: 6 percent less for single workers, married couples, and families.

headline.main: My Health Insurance Rates Just Went Down Again

docs.abstract: The e-mail reinforces something multiple commenters to my earlier posts have said: sick workers will cost you, and the cost can be substantial.
docs.snippet: The e-mail reinforces something multiple commenters to my earlier posts have said: sick workers will cost you, and the cost can be substantial.

docs.abstract: Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease answers questions posed by India Ink readers.
docs.snippet: Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease answers questions posed by India Ink readers.

docs.lead_paragraph: India Ink asked Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease, who was profiled in a recent New York Times article, to answer readers' questions about the Indian labor market and his company's philosophy. Readers posed tough queries about his business model, his competitors and the hurdles that employers and job seekers face in India. The questions and Mr. Sabharwal's answers have been edited.
docs.abstract: Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease answers questions posed by India Ink readers.
docs.snippet: Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease answers questions posed by India Ink readers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The change reflects demographics, in part, but also government cost-cutting that has resulted in less generous pay and benefits.

headline.seo: More Public Sector Workers Are Retiring
headline.main: Many Workers in Public Sector Retiring Sooner
headline.print_headline: Many Workers In Public Sector Retiring Sooner

docs.abstract: Growing number of public-sector workers across the United States are retiring; as states and cities struggling to resolve paralyzing budget shortfalls send workers on unpaid furloughs, freeze wages and cut back on retirement benefits, workers are making plans to get out before their security is eroded even further.
docs.snippet: The change reflects demographics, in part, but also government cost-cutting that has resulted in less generous pay and benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate never tells the American people what it will truly take to cut spending and balance the budget.

headline.seo: Missing Details of Mr. Romney’s Fiscal Plan

docs.abstract: Editorial asserts that Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's proposed fiscal plan is vague and misleading; notes that plan does not acknowledge the true cost of cutting both spending and taxes, which would lead to the elimination of popular programs and services and inflict misery on the poor and working class.
docs.snippet: The Republican presidential candidate never tells the American people what it will truly take to cut spending and balance the budget.

docs.lead_paragraph: In 17 months, Dr. Donald Berwick accomplished a lot in improving Medicare. He could have done so much more if Republicans had confirmed him.
docs.abstract: Joe Nocera Op-Ed column praises Dr Donald Berwick on eve of his departure as the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for his work in improving the quality of health care and cutting costs; asserts that the Republicans, who refused to confirm Berwick, may regret that they forced out the best man for the job.
docs.snippet: In 17 months, Dr. Donald Berwick accomplished a lot in improving Medicare. He could have done so much more if Republicans had confirmed him.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: An antitrust hearing will examine assertions by opponents that competition and costs will suffer if a deal between Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions proceeds.

headline.seo: Express Scripts-Medco Merger Raises Antitrust Concerns

docs.abstract: Express Scripts' proposed $29 billion acquisition of Medco is expected to face intense scrutiny from a Senate panel examining potential antitrust concerns raised by the merger of the country's two largest pharmacy benefit managers; opponents assert that competition and costs will suffer if a deal is completed between the two companies, which manage prescription drugs for more than 115 million people and handle one of every three prescriptions filled in the United States.
docs.snippet: An antitrust hearing will examine assertions by opponents that competition and costs will suffer if a deal between Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions proceeds.

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and NATASHA SINGER

docs.lead_paragraph: Anticipating security threats is not merely a matter of reasoning abstractly about how new technology might raise new risks; it requires an understanding of human nature.

headline.seo: Stefan Savage: Girding for Digital Threats We Haven’t Imagined Yet
headline.main: In Planning Digital Defenses, the Biggest Obstacle Is Human Ingenuity
headline.print_headline: In Planning Digital Defenses, the Biggest Obstacle Is Human Ingenuity

docs.abstract: Essay by Stefan Savage of the University of California, San Diego, discusses the evolution and future of computer security.
docs.snippet: Anticipating security threats is not merely a matter of reasoning abstractly about how new technology might raise new risks; it requires an understanding of human nature.

headline.main: Labor Department Seeks Tougher Rules on 'Multiple-Employer' Plans

docs.abstract: The federal agency says it wants more authority to crack down on insurance plans that take advantage of small businesses and their employees.
docs.snippet: The federal agency says it wants more authority to crack down on insurance plans that take advantage of small businesses and their employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal officials hope to crack down more effectively on operators of "multiple employer" health plans that have defrauded small businesses and their workers of hundreds of millions of dollars, often leaving them stuck with unpaid medical bills, according to new rules proposed Monday by the Obama administration under the health care legislation.

headline.main: Labor Department Seeks Tougher Rules on 'Multiple-Employer' Plans

docs.abstract: The federal agency says it wants more authority to crack down on insurance plans that take advantage of small businesses and their employees.
docs.snippet: The federal agency says it wants more authority to crack down on insurance plans that take advantage of small businesses and their employees.
